Award.AwardTitle: Can Students Use Assessment-based Double-loop Learning to Improve Their Design Skills?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer Engineering (32)
This is a proof of concept project that is educating students in the use of "double-loop learning" to improve their self-regulated learning (SRL) skills and thereby increase their learning capacity and their design skills. The study builds on earlier work funded by NSF that developed assessments of students' knowledge and skill in the design process. The specific objective of this project are: (1) to contribute to the understanding of how students learn to create open-ended designs and develop reflective practice, (2) to provide materials and an instructional model that can applied to other courses, and (3) to develop a validated instrument for measuring students' design process skill and reflective practice. The study has three phases. In the first phase the assessment instrument is being given to all students enrolled in electrical and computer engineering (ECE) to establish baseline performance levels both across the curriculum and in the computer engineering design courses. In the second phase, the junior-level computer engineering design course is being revised so that students use the process assessments as a basis for continuous improvement. After each third of the course, students will take the process assessments and use the results to devise improvement plans. The change in their understanding and use of appropriate design process, the quality of their design artifacts, and the impact on their reflective practice skills and attitudes is then being compared to that of students who took the course the previous year in the traditional format.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The success of the quality model (double-loop learning) in other areas has led ABET to call for its use in improving curricula. In an earlier National Science Foundation (NSF) grant assessments of students’ knowledge and skill in design process had been developed.  The first phase of this project was to give those assessments to all students enrolled in Electrical and Computer Engineering to validate the use of these assessments in the Department’s continuous improvement of its curriculum. The results indicated that more advanced students scored higher on all three assessments, but that they did not improve from the beginning to the end of their design course at any level (freshman, sophomore, junior or senior). This pattern of results suggests that specific design courses are not successfully teaching design process, but that as students increase their expertise, they intuit some aspects of design process.

In the second phase the junior-level computer engineering design course was restructured so that students take the process assessment as a basis for continuous improvement. After each third of the course, they took the process assessments, and, armed with the results as well as assessments of their design products, devised improvement plans. The change in their understanding and use of appropriate design process components and the quality of their design artifacts was compared to that of students who took the course the previous year in the traditional format. The students in the experimental course showed improvement on both the simulation task and the project reports from the beginning of the semester to the end, whereas the students in the same class the year before showed no improvement.  This result is particularly impressive because the instructor gave no instruction in design process. Anecdotally, the student members of the Faculty Curriculum Committee, after they took this course, convinced the faculty that they needed to incorporate this technique in all their design courses and the faculty began work to do this.

These two studies are the first demonstration of the role that assessing design process skills can play in applying the quality model to engineering education. Its impact is two-fold. First, it demonstrates to engineering faculty that design process skills can be described and assessed and should help to cure the widespread false belief that engineering design skill is an intuitive ability that students either have or do not have. Second, it demonstrates that the quality model can be implemented to student learning.

Broader Impact

This research addresses the most basic and important question in education--what can educators do to help students develop habits of mind that will allow them to work more effectively and to continue to develop their expertise through their lifetimes? Of course, one study cannot solve this age-old question, but it can provide the groundwork. The strategies and assessments used in this project can be immediately applied to most engineering contexts with only the development of new content examples.

In addition, the approach is more widely applicable to any discipline whose practice requires open-ended, structured thinking. The principles have already been applied to the curriculum-wide assessment of research design in psychology.
